office:text.text:p: BULGARIAN ACADEMY OF SCIENCES
Software Reliability of the Computer Systems in the Light of Revolution 4.0
Nikolay Petrov*, Todor Balabanov**, Ivan Petrov***
* Faculty of Engineering and Pedagogy of Sliven - Technical University of Sofia
** Institute of Information and Communication Technologies - Bulgarian Academy of Sciences
*** Paysafe Group, Sofia, Bulgaria
Emails: nikipetrov_1953@abv.bg todorb@iinf.bas.bg ivan.petrov@paysafe.com

text:span.text:span: together areas which are not normally classified as an industry. It concerns machines with wireless data transfer, sensors that can

the entire production line and make decisions on its own. The core are automation and data exchange in manufacturing technologies and processes. In such progressive expansion of technologies the reliability of the software components becomes a critical aspect

office:text.text:p: 1. Introduction

A basic prerequisite for research in software reliability is that the ideal objects in man, nature and society are not perfect. The quality of their conformity to material things is not absolute and vice versa. It follows that there may be a time when an ideal object is in poor conformity. If we define that moment, phenomenon, or event as object rejection, the term "conceptual object reliability" or "conceptual reliability" becomes meaningful. It is important for the development of reliability because linking reliability with the quality of compliance is the second direction for developing the concept of "reliability", since in complex systems we have abandoned the concept of "failure" because of the possibility of redundancy [1].

An objective substantive reason for the reliability of conceptual objects is the presence of errors in the created software object, which is why the realized quality of compliance does not always meet the expected (predicted).

From the point of view of the reliability of a conceptual object, the software is characterized as follows: any software product, with strictly fixed input data and absolutely reliable equipment, is executed by a strictly defined algorithm and connection at the call point. However, the combinatorial nature and random change of input data, accumulated information and the large number of conditional transitions create many different branches of the overall computing information and communication process that cannot be fully verified (some of them are unlikely to be implemented due to the low probability of the corresponding combination of input).

As a result, the "side effect" phenomenon known in the software appears. A side effect is understood to be different results from the execution of the same software product or module, with the same input parameters. In both cases, this is called software failure. For software support, failure may also be self-eliminating, in which the transition from incapacity to work is done without outside interference and for a very short time. Such a self-defeating failure has already been defined as a failure [2,3].

Reliability of software is its ability to deliver predicted (expected) outputs whenever inputs meet specifications. The definition belongs to Glenford Myers [1]. The reliability of the software is thus determined by: 1) distortion of input information, 2) undetected bugs in the code, 3) the quality of the operator's work with the software and the training opportunity, 4) attack by viral agents and others.
The first two cases mentioned above do not express the intrinsic property of the software, but rather are its function. Here is the fine difference between objective and conceptual reliability.

As an important difference in the definition of a self-repair failure entity operator error, a software fault is any situation of endless cycles in runtime that makes it impossible to complete a function in the software itself. Software failure is an error (including distorted input).
2. Model for growing the reliability of software

Software reliability is usually written and talked about only in terms of errors. For this reason, ensuring the reliability of software includes: error-making, error detection, error correction or omissions, and the creation of robust software (fault-tolerant computing tools).

Fault tolerance is defined as the ability of the system to handle and correct errors that have occurred. The system is fault tolerant if it continues to function in the presence of failures. Software architecture resiliency at the architectural level is a relatively new area of research that has received a great deal of attention in recent years. Simultaneously meeting the requirements for resilience, information security and speed is a complex research and practical task.

The problems of resilience in the theory and analysis of complex software systems include the following: 1) formulation of the basic concepts used in the study and application of software resilience, 2) detection and study of the main factors determining the resilience of complex software systems, 3) selection and justification of reliability criteria for complexes of programs of different type and purpose, 4) defect and error investigation, as well as the dynamics of their changes in debugging and escorting is, as well as the impact of software reliability indicators, 5) research and development of methods for structural construction of complex software systems, providing the necessary resilience, 6) research of methods and means for control and protection against software failures, computing process and data through the use of various types of surplus and other protections (eg noise protection), 7) development of methods and tools for determining and forecasting the resilience characteristics of the software life cycle systems, taking into account their functional purpose, complexity, structural design and implementation technology.
The difference between the reliability of a technical object and the reliability of the software is shown qualitatively in Fig. 1, by comparing the failure rates.

Over time, the intensity of software failures decreases at the expense of the continuous detection and elimination of failures in the hardware (technical object). The slope of the curve is the steepest at the beginning, since most errors are detected and corrected when setting up and testing the software before it goes into regular operation. The description of the behavior of software over time, depending on the errors contained therein, is performed through reliability models. The models differ in the source applications they are based on.

text:span.text:span: Fig. 1. The difference between the reliability of a technical object

office:text.text:p: The software reliability growth model is applicable during the software development testing phase and quantifies the reliability of the software in terms of the estimated number of software errors left in the software or the estimated (estimated) intervals between crashes (bugs) in software. The growth of software reliability is determined by the following phenomenon - the number of software bugs remaining in the system decreases as testing progresses.

text:p.text:span: For the purpose of creating models and analyzing software growth, calendar or CPU time is often used (as a unit of measure for the period of detection of available errors in it). The appropriate (applicable) unit for the software detection period is also the number of test samples (tests). The software reliability growth model for this particular case is called the discrete reliability growth model. Generally, software reliability growth models are grouped into two classes of models: exponential and S-shaped [

office:text.text:p: The most important thing for both models is that they have the same asymptotic behavior, which means that the speed of bug detection decreases with the increase in the number of detected (and corrected) software testing.
Therefore, the total number of bugs reported approaches its final value asymptotically, in accordance with the law adopted to change current reliability (Tab. 1).

The literature on software bugs is extensive and varied. Anyone who intends to use these models will face two problems. First, which of the many models would be appropriate? Second, how can the parameters of the models and their reliability be evaluated?

Choosing the right model is not easy. The American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics (AIAA) recommends one of the following four models: the Jelynsky-Moranda, Littlewood-Veral, Musa-Okumoto and Schneidwind models. It should be borne in mind that there is no detailed and openly available set of experimental data available to provide or guide the user in selecting a model for testing the reliability of the software. This contrasts sharply with hardware reliability modeling, where systematic data collection efforts have formed the basis of much of the theory.

Software reliability models are based on plausible arguments. The best one has to offer is to investigate the degree of error as a function of testing and find out: which model does it follow? For example, if the error rate seems to exhibit an exponential relationship at the time of the study, then we might consider using the Musa-Okumoto model. Once a suitable model has been selected, the parameters can be estimated using the maximum likelihood method.

After doing everything we can to reduce the error rate of individual programs, we must turn to fault tolerance methods to reduce the impact of software errors (defects, bugs). Both in technical systems and in software, an important step in this is to reduce the errors that should be discovered in the actual experimentation or simulation of a model related to its logic of creation and application, as well as its evaluation and management procedures. risk in any technical, economic and / or social system and information management environment because software users are machines, humans and humans.

The ideal or conceptual environment of their shared existence requires an assessment of the reliability of information, because information is the basis for knowledge, new experience, and providing for subsequent changes thereto. In this context, research is needed on the reliability of the information, its standard use and creative application in the actions and activities of the subjects, as well as on its effective management. Information and knowledge are the foundation in any kind of model and type of management, system and technology.
3. Conclusions
As a result of the conducted research on the topic, the following conclusions were obtained:

An equation for software reliability is derived based on the Nelson model. The methods used for this purpose, together with the principles on which they are based, form the main (main) part of the theory and practice of software reliability.

When developing software programs, it is necessary to provide mechanisms for storing the current state (system parameters and intermediate results) of information, close enough in time to the time of the glitch.
The research and development of conceptual reliability opens new possibilities for theoretical and applied knowledge about the reliability and security of systems and technologies.
